title: AI as Conversation Participant: Tools and Understanding
mainTopics: AI as participant in group conversations

aiAsParticipant.description: John Warinner's epiphany: Why one-on-ones with ChatGPT when LLMs could participate in group conversations?
keyPoints: Everyone having revealing one-on-one AI explorations
Want to share, but bombarding each other with loquacious exchanges
Bandwidth problem: can't digest everyone's 2,000-4,000 word transcripts
Light bulb: Why aren't LLMs just participants in THIS conversation?
Asked ChatGPT: how far off? Response: couple years away, in the pipeline
Would be a different chapter than current one-on-one era
Might temper frustration of trying to share everything
aiAsParticipant.impact: Reframes problem from 'how do we share AI conversations?' to 'why aren't AIs here with us?'

mappingVsMap.description: Gene Bellinger wisdom applied to AI conversations
mappingVsMap.geneQuote: The value is the gerund - it's the mapping, not the map
mappingVsMap.johnApplication: Greatest value is in the conversation, not the product of the conversation
jerryExperience: Other people's maps often impenetrable unless unpacked slowly
Gene Bellinger builds maps piece by piece - takes effort on both sides
Small percentage can navigate Jerry's Brain solo
Few deeply understand WHY he curated specific contexts
dougExtension: It's not JUST the exercise of mapping
Gene's maps create models, reflect living systems
Reveal complex systems, identify leverage points
Inform next action, where to focus intervention or contribution

sharingAIConversations.description: Solutions to the 'long AI transcript' problem
sharingAIConversations.jerryProposal: Post link to conversation URL instead of pasting full text - those up for long read can go, others skip
staceySolution: Ran long AI chat (about shutdown) through LLM to create podcast
Created very short podcast as 'great beginning point for a conversation'
Asks good questions (what Stacey loved most)
alexInsight: Email is for snappy, short things to act on
Long read is different allocation - 'I'm not doing email anymore, I am in deep study mode'
Need to consciously shift mental modes

whyAreWeHere.description: Explicit articulation of individual purposes for OGM
whyAreWeHere.trigger: Alex Kladitis asked 'What do people want out of this group, or this conversation?'
whyAreWeHere.alexPurpose: Hear new perspectives or existing perspectives from different people with different viewpoint. Makes me think.
jerryPurpose: Learn stuff I would never figure out - people share what they're finding/thinking
'I hadn't put that plus that together in my head' - curation over time gets better, knowledge accumulates
Love who shows up, social interactions
Love that we know what we do - 4-5 years of history, not 'what do you do?'
Bringing people together who then go off and have conversations, do projects - 'if three people met and did something they loved, that's gold'
Frustrated desire: 'I'd really like to build a global mind... We really haven't done that. We haven't done much of that at all.'
dougPurpose: Understanding - not agreement, just common understanding
Get on same page at most simple, basic, fundamental semantic level
My meaning and somebody else's meaning is aligned, recognized, understood
Better decisions, contribute positively, minimize destruction
LLMs enable handling complex array of variables in real-time like never before

enshittificationAndMonetization.description: Can platforms sustain without falling into enshittification?
staceyObservation: Negatives came when monetization came in
Don't throw out positive (creating for community) with negative (monetization)
enshittificationAndMonetization.jerryCorrection: Facebook birth story actually Face Smash to rate 'hot babes' on Harvard campus - opposite of the energy you're bringing
gilQuestions: Is enshittification tightly correlated with monetization?
How do you build something with appropriate reach that can be sustained economically without falling into enshittification machine?
Does avoiding enshittification depend on volunteer labor?
Volunteers have sources of income elsewhere - tied into enshittification for most of their lives
Open source brilliance of last 50 years came from this, but it's not a sustainable strategy
enshittificationAndMonetization.jerryResponse: Big question: is it possible to have viable, sustainable, ongoing concern software that doesn't need to go down the enshittification rat hole?

thinkertoysDemonstration.description: Shawn Murphy building the tool OGM is talking about
whatItDoes: Outputs in Turtle (graph knowledge representation format)
Pump into Thinkertoys, immediately graph it
Multiple visualizations: tabular, graphical, wiggly graph things
AI populates shared knowledge collaboration workspace
Group springboards off AI output, continues working together
thinkertoysDemonstration.lastWeekendTest: Worked with different crew Saturday, exploring topic in near real-time
thinkertoysDemonstration.jerryInvite: Send invite to OGM list for pop-up call to try the tool

aiToolsInPractice.description: Examples of AI tools already working
aiToolsInPractice.staceyPodcast: LLM converts long text to short podcast as conversation starter, asks good questions
jerryFocusGroup: Broken into breakouts to discuss questions briefly
AI summarizing each group, cross-fertilizing insights
AI: 'I think this is what you said' or 'I think this is what you've agreed on'
'AI was being really, really helpful in ways I hadn't experienced before in that kind of setting'
'I look forward to having AIs participating as excellent listeners and summarizers'
aiToolsInPractice.gilFathom: Note-taker AI (Jerry resents: 'when Gil shows up, he shows up with like 3 different note-takers')

postOutsideIn.description: Jerry's old policy proposal for private communities
postOutsideIn.problem: People post brilliant things in private forums - can't retweet, repost, point to them. Stuff trapped in 'bit bucket'.
postOutsideIn.solution: Post outside in - write interesting idea as public post (blog), then share link in private community
postOutsideIn.benefit: Conversation can happen in more public view, good stuff not trapped, communities move but work remains accessible

theWellProblem.firstOnlineExperience: The Well (Sausalito), bulletin board system PicoSpan
problem: Can't read through long list of posts and remember where the good ones were
'Really good one here, whole stretch of crap in between, really good one here'
Knew really good stuff was floating by
Could never keep myself up-to-date in conversation
theWellProblem.relevance: One of many facets of what we're trying to solve

insight: LLMs might be really nice companions for long, threaded discussions
Might be excellent summarizers or highlighters of what actually happened
TLDR agent might be real boon
Deeper conversations are very important to have

decisionMaking.description: Ultimate purpose: helping people make better decisions
framework: Getting to common understanding at semantic level
Gene's maps reveal complex systems, identify leverage points
Help marshal much more complex, diverse array of variables
Make better decisions, better choices, better actions
Better = contribute positively to value and quality of life
Better = minimize impact, destruction, adverse consequence
LLMs enable real-time handling of complexity at unprecedented level
'At the end of the day, it's helping with decision-making'
decisionMaking.jerryAlignment: We're on the same mission - helping people make better decisions, achieve mutual understanding despite stumbling blocks like language and technology

storiesShared.summary: Couple years ago, pi.ai said 'what's on your mind?' 90 minutes later, best interview ever. Kept saying 'it sounds like you said this, do you mean this?' Raised the conversation. Not Eliza, not stochastic parrot - deeply understanding. 'Oh my god, oh my god!' Shook him a little bit. Hasn't gone back to that thread. Trying to figure out how to incorporate AI into life more.
storiesShared.impact: Example of transformative AI conversation experience

storiesShared.summary: Bulletin board system PicoSpan, Sausalito. Good stuff floating by but couldn't keep up-to-date. Can't remember where good posts were in long threads.
storiesShared.impact: Longstanding problem of knowledge discovery in forums

storiesShared.summary: Someone shared long AI chat about shutdown. Stacey ran it through LLM to create short podcast. 'Great beginning point for a conversation.' Loved that it asked good questions.
